responses.content: Meta Superintelligence Labs now combines elite research talent with massive multi-gigawatt clusters so we can build frontier models and be ready for optimistic timelines; the same capacity also powers our core apps while we unify our large transformers into more general systems.

Unifying our recommendation and ad models increased time spent (5% Facebook, 10% Threads) with video surging and Reels now at a $50B+ ARR; AI ranking uplifts and Advantage+ automation (Vibes, generative creative, Lattice, Andromeda) keep conversions improving and power the $60B+ run rate for fully automated tools.

Meta AI reaches over 1B monthly actives and continues to drive new content formats (Vibes), while business AI pilots are automating the full sale funnel across WhatsApp, Messenger, and websites, and we expect frontier models to unlock even more utility and monetization over time.

AI glasses are front and center—latest Ray-Ban Meta, Oakley Meta Vanguards, and the new display prototype sold out in days—Quest remains engaged ahead of holidays, and we’re expanding manufacturing to meet demand for AI-first wearables.

Revenue of $51.2B (+26% / +25% cc), expenses $30.7B (+32%), operating income $20.5B (40% margin), net income $2.7B (includes $15.9B noncash tax charge), EPS $1.05, CapEx $19.4B, free cash flow $10.6B; repurchases $3.2B, dividends $1.3B, cash $44.4B.
3.5B daily actives, 14% more ad impressions, 10% higher price, $50.1B ads plus $690M other revenue (WhatsApp subscriptions/Meta Verified), with video time up 30% and Threads DAUs hitting 150M.

Reality Labs revenue hit $470M (+74%) thanks to AI glasses while Quest lacked a new launch; RL expense ~$4.4B. Infrastructure spend remains central—CapEx guide now $70-72B and 2026 will see even more growth, supported by staged data center build-outs and financing partnerships.

Q4 revenue guide $56-59B, total 2025 expenses $116-118B, tax rate 12-15% (accounting charge from new U.S. law but future cash savings expected), continuing EU DMA/LPA engagement and U.S. youth litigation; plan for 2026 includes higher infra/comp costs with even faster expense and CapEx growth.

questions: Which technological constraints are you prioritizing next for Superintelligence Labs, and what upcoming recommendation enhancements will drive further engagement across the family of apps?
Does your open-source philosophy change as you push toward personal super intelligence, and will Meta continue financing the infrastructure ramp internally or seek third-party partners?
How does current capacity serve both internal research and profitable core AI workloads, and what evidence gives you confidence the GenAI investments will eventually pay off?
How do you balance Superintelligence initiatives with near-term products like Vibes, Advantage+, and AI glasses, and where do you expect the value to accrue across apps versus new experiences?
What metrics do you use to track Superintelligence progress, and has the cadence of investments shifted relative to core performance?
How will future models like Behemoth accelerate Meta AI adoption (especially via WhatsApp) and unlock new monetization hooks?
Are AI glasses scaling ahead of plan, and do they complement or eventually replace smartphones?
How are you managing SBC dilution while hiring aggressively for AI and infrastructure?
With a leading frontier model on the horizon, where do you expect the value to accrue—core platforms, new apps, services, or hardware?
What signals from Meta AI adoption encourage you that a monetization path exists, and how far along are you on the scale/build/ramp cycle?
What behaviors are you seeing from the >1B users of Meta AI, and how will exporting frontier models into consumer products change those interactions?
